details.title: Alternative time scales for systems with random usage
details.standardTitle: Alternative time scales for systems with random usage

p: Maxim S. Finkelstein received the M.Sc. (1971) degree from St. Petersburg State University (Russia), and the Ph.D. (1979) and D.Sc. (1992) degrees in operations research from St. Petersburg Elektropribor Institute.

He is a Professor with the department of Mathematical Statistics, University of the Free State, South Africa. He has published more than 100 papers on various aspects of reliability & stochastics. He has authored four books published in Russian.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. Stat., Univ. of the Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa
authors.name: M.S. Finkelstein

details.abstract: In various reliability applications, there can be different time scales in which to measure time to failure, or assess the performance of objects. For instance, for automobiles the chronological age & the total number of driving hours, as measures of usage, are good candidates for the time scale. An impact of a random usage on some properties of time to failure distribution functions is studied. It is shown that a random usage can change the shape of the failure rate of an object compared with the shape of the failure rate for the deterministic usage. Specifically, the sharply increasing failure rate can turn into a decreasing one, which is, in fact, surprising. The random usage can also change the aging properties of distributions under consideration, and this should be taken into account in applications. Several simple examples illustrate the developed concept.

context.text: While defining the warranty period of some products, for instance, several (usually two) time scales should be taken into consideration, as discussed in Farewell and Cox [2], Kordonsky and Gertbach [6], [7], Lawless et al. [8], Oakes [10], Singpurwalla and Wilson [11] and in the recent paper of Duchense and Lawless [1].

context.text: Relations (1) & (2) actually define the scale transformations for lifetime random variables in the following way [3]:where \$Z({t})\$ is a time to failure Cdf in chronological scale \$t\$, and \$W({t})\$ is an increasing continuous function of \$t\$, \$W({0}) = 0\$, \$W({t}) \le t\$, \$W({t})\to \infty \$ as \$t \to \infty \$.

context.text: The failure rate of the mixture (9) can be defined as [5], [9]:where \$g({w\vert t})\$ is a conditional pdf of \$W\$ given that time to failure described by the mixture Cdf \$Z({t})\$ exceeds \$t~({T \ge t})\$:.

Specifically, for the Weibull Cdf with increasing baseline failure rate (which is often used in automobile reliability analysis [12]) \$\lambda({x}) = \lambda x^{b}\$; \$\lambda > 0\$, \$b >0\$, the following relation takes place as \$t \to \infty \$ [5]:where \$c > 0\$ is a constant.
Relation (13) was obtained in [5] for the specific case when the mixing pdf \$g({w})\$ is a gamma pdf with support in \$[ {0,\infty })\$.
